goal.en: Fate and Transport of Contaminants in the Environment
goal.ch: 污染物環境宿命與傳輸

content.en:
This course covers the fundamental physical, chemical, and biological principles governing the behavior of contaminants in aquatic and terrestrial environmental compartments, including surface water, groundwater, soil, and sediment. The material is presented in an intuitive format instead of a rigorously mathematical framework. Linkages to health effects, sources and controls, and policy aspects will be discussed. Students will learn to solve practical, quantitative problems considering both reaction and transport of contaminants in the environment.
I. Basic Concepts
1. Control volumes, mass balance and units
2. Advective- and dispersive-transport
3. Chemical equilibrium and kinetics
4. Phase partitioning
II. Surface Waters
1. Physical transport in rivers, lakes, and wetlands
2. Sediment transport and paleolimnology
3. Air-water exchange (Henry’s Law)
4. Water-sediment or biota transfer
5. Ecosystem characteristics and redox chemistry
6. BOD/DO modeling and biotransformations
7. Abiotic chemical transformations
III. Groundwater and Aquifers
1. Physics of groundwater movement
2. Transient well hydraulics and retardation
3. Unsaturated zone flow and bioremediation
IV. Case Studies
1. Arsenic in the groundwater of Bangladesh
2. Geochemical software demo PHREEQC
V. Webinars
1. Philip Gschwend (MIT)
2. Charles Harvey (MIT)
VI. Documentaries
1. A civil action
2. Dark waters
